5.Comments for translators: Here "universal" means "can be used anywhere/in any situation"

7.Comments for translators: The language you are translating into: AS IT REFERS TO ITSELF (using its own alphabet/character set),. e.g. Deutsch, 汉语

8.Comments for translators: The language you are translating into: AS IT IS REFERRED TO IN ENGLISH e.g. German， Chinese

11.text: This document is a set of language learning materials compiled exclusively for use by Jehovah’s Witnesses.

12.text: The entries, definitions and other information contained herein can be easily translated into almost any language. New editions of these materials can then be produced simply by combining any two translations. It is hoped that this framework will reduce the workload of language instructors, and contribute to the effectiveness of Witnesses serving in foreign language fields around the world.

13.text: These language materials may be circulated free of charge among active Witnesses. They may not be given or lent to others in any format.

18.Comments for translators: This is a heading. Please translate it.

19.text: “Algebraic” notation used to show where additional words can be placed in relation to the expression that is being defined.

20.text: Words that might need to be added to the expression in certain situations because the language requires it.

21.text: An alternative word that might need to be substituted for part of the expression in certain situations because the language requires it.

22.text: An optional word or phrase that is commonly added to this expression without changing its meaning significantly.

23.text: An alternative word or phrase that is commonly substituted for part of the expression without changing its meaning significantly.

24.text: The semicolon separates multiple expressions that have similar meanings.

25.text: A complex phrase (e.g. involving a verb and other words) can be inserted at this point.

26.text: Additional description or examples to help the reader understand the sense of the word being defined. This information only appears in definitions and may vary from language to language.

27.text: Curly brackets contain extra language-specific information about the target expression. This may include grammatical information or the symbols shown below.

28.text: This word or phrase should be used with caution for cultural or other reasons.

29.text: This is only an approximate translation of the definition.

30.text: This word or phrase is rarely used in the target language.

31.text: No translation has been provided for this word by our translators.

32.text: This is a form of the word or phrase that is commonly used in a region other than the main territory where this language is spoken ("internet"-style notation has been used, e.g. .hk = Hong Kong)

33.text: The theocratic term being defined currently has no clear equivalent in Watch Tower Society publications in this language. (This symbol will usually be used in conjunction with other symbols)

34.text: This is our translators’ attempt at an accurate translation of the term. (This symbol is normally only used for theocratic terms that currently have no clear equivalent in the target language)

35.text: This is the corresponding term that is commonly used by brothers during meetings. (This symbol is normally only used for theocratic terms that currently have no clear equivalent in the target language)

790.Comments for translators: I have deliberately not included the word "Please" in the following phrases, because it is not always necessary when we are praying in English. You should not translate these phrases literally if it is not appropriate or natural in your language. I have included separate entries for the word "Please" later on. Let me know if this arrangement is not appropriate for your language.
